docs.title: Welcome to NeatCLI
docs.text: A smart CLI tool to organize and clean up messy directories

docs.title: What is NeatCLI?
docs.text:
NeatCLI is a powerful command-line tool written in Rust that helps you automatically organize files, find duplicates, clean up old files, and maintain tidy directories. It's designed to be fast, safe, and flexible.

Perfect for

  • 📂 Organizing your Downloads folder
  • 📸 Sorting photos by date or camera
  • 🎵 Organizing music by artist/album
  • 🗑️ Cleaning up old files and duplicates
  • 👀 Watching folders for automatic organization

docs.title: Features
docs.text:
• 🗂️ Smart Organization - Organize files by type, date, extension, or metadata (EXIF/ID3)
  • 🔍 Duplicate Detection - Find duplicate files using SHA256 content hashing
  • 🖼️ Similar Images - Detect visually similar images using perceptual hashing
  • 🧹 Cleanup Tools - Remove old files and empty folders
  • ⏪ Undo Support - Full operation history with undo capability
  • 👁️ Watch Mode - Auto-organize new files as they appear
  • 🖥️ Interactive TUI - Visual file management interface
  • ⚡ Fast & Safe - Written in Rust, with dry-run by default

docs.title: Quick Example
docs.text:
# Preview what will happen (dry-run is default)
neatcli organize ~/Downloads

# Actually organize the files
neatcli organize ~/Downloads --execute

# Find duplicate files
neatcli duplicates ~/Pictures

# Show directory statistics
neatcli stats ~/Documents

docs.title: clean
docs.text: Remove old files and empty folders from a directory.

docs.title: Usage
docs.text:
neatcli clean [OPTIONS] <PATH>

Arguments:

  • PATH - Directory to clean (required)

docs.title: Options
docs.text: Flag Description Example --older-than Delete files older than duration --older-than 30d --empty-folders Remove empty folders --trash Move to trash instead of deleting --execute -e Execute the cleanup --dry-run -n Preview what will be deleted --min-size Minimum file size --min-size 1KB --max-size Maximum file size --max-size 10MB

docs.title: Duration Format
docs.text:
The --older-than flag accepts various duration formats:

Format Example Meaning Days 30d 30 days Weeks 2w 2 weeks Hours 24h 24 hours

docs.title: Remove Old Files
docs.text:
# Preview files older than 30 days
neatcli clean ~/Downloads --older-than 30d

# Delete files older than 30 days (permanent)
neatcli clean ~/Downloads --older-than 30d --execute

# Move old files to trash (safer)
neatcli clean ~/Downloads --older-than 30d --trash --execute

docs.title: Remove Empty Folders
docs.text:
# Preview empty folders
neatcli clean ~/Projects --empty-folders

# Remove empty folders
neatcli clean ~/Projects --empty-folders --execute

docs.title: Combined Cleanup
docs.text:
# Remove old files AND empty folders
neatcli clean ~/Downloads --older-than 7d --empty-folders --trash --execute

docs.title: With Size Filters
docs.text:
# Only delete small old files (< 1MB)
neatcli clean ~/Downloads --older-than 30d --max-size 1MB --execute

docs.title: duplicates
docs.text: Find duplicate files by content hash.

docs.title: Usage
docs.text: neatcli duplicates [OPTIONS] <PATH>

docs.title: How It Works
docs.text:
NeatCLI uses SHA256 hashing to find files with identical content:

  1. Size grouping - Files are grouped by size (different sizes can't be duplicates)
  2. Hash calculation - SHA256 hash is computed for files with matching sizes
  3. Duplicate detection - Files with identical hashes are duplicates

Performance

Only files with matching sizes are hashed, making the process very fast even for large directories.

docs.title: Options
docs.text: Flag Description --delete Delete duplicates (keeps first file) --trash Move to trash instead of permanent delete --json Export results as JSON --csv Export results as CSV --execute -e Execute deletion --min-size Minimum file size --max-size Maximum file size --after Files modified after date --before Files modified before date

docs.title: Find Duplicates
docs.text:
# Find duplicates in Pictures folder
neatcli duplicates ~/Pictures

Output: 

→ Scanning /Users/you/Pictures for duplicate files...
  Found 1234 files to analyze

Duplicate Files Found:
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

  Group 1 (5.2 MB) - 3 copies:
    ● /Users/you/Pictures/photo.jpg
    ○ /Users/you/Pictures/backup/photo.jpg
    ○ /Users/you/Pictures/old/photo_copy.jpg

  Group 2 (2.1 MB) - 2 copies:
    ● /Users/you/Pictures/vacation.png
    ○ /Users/you/Pictures/exports/vacation.png

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

Summary: 3 duplicate files in 2 groups
Wasted space: 9.4 MB could be recovered by removing duplicates

ℹ Use --delete --execute to remove duplicates (keeps first file in each group).

docs.title: Delete Duplicates
docs.text:
# Move duplicates to trash (keeps first file)
neatcli duplicates ~/Pictures --delete --trash --execute

Which File is Kept?

The first file in each group (marked with ●) is always kept. Duplicates (marked with ○) are deleted.

neatcli duplicates ~/Pictures --json > duplicates.json

# Export to CSV
neatcli duplicates ~/Pictures --csv > duplicates.csv

docs.title: history
docs.text: View the history of operations performed by neatcli.

docs.title: Usage
docs.text: neatcli history

docs.title: Description
docs.text:
The history command displays a log of all operations performed by neatcli, including:

  • File moves from organize command
  • File deletions from clean command
  • Duplicate file removals from duplicates command
  • Similar image removals from similar command

This information is stored in ~/.neat/history.json and is used by the undo command to reverse operations.

docs.title: Output
docs.text:
Operation History
─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
[2024-12-20 10:30:15] organize
  Moved: report.pdf → Documents/report.pdf
  Moved: photo.jpg → Images/photo.jpg

[2024-12-20 11:15:00] clean --older-than 30d
  Deleted: old_log.txt
  Deleted: temp_file.tmp

docs.title: History Storage
docs.text:
History is stored at:

~/.neat/history.json

Automatic Cleanup

History entries older than 30 days are automatically cleaned up to prevent the file from growing too large.

docs.text: Command Description undo Undo the last operation using history organize Organize files (creates history entries) clean Clean files (creates history entries)

docs.title: organize
docs.text: Organize files by type, date, extension, or metadata.

docs.title: Usage
docs.text:
neatcli organize [OPTIONS] [PATH]

Arguments:

  • PATH - Directory to organize (default: current directory)

docs.title: Organization Modes
docs.text:
Choose how files should be organized:

Mode Flag Result By Type --by-type Images/, Documents/, Videos/, etc. By Date --by-date 2024/01/, 2024/02/, etc. By Extension --by-extension PDF/, JPG/, MP4/, etc. By Camera --by-camera Camera model from EXIF By Date Taken --by-date-taken Date from EXIF metadata By Artist --by-artist Artist from audio tags By Album --by-album Artist/Album/ structure

Default Mode

docs.title: similar
docs.text: Find visually similar images using perceptual hashing.

docs.title: Usage
docs.text: neatcli similar [OPTIONS] <PATH>

docs.title: How It Works
docs.text:
Unlike duplicates which finds exact copies, similar finds images that look alike:

  1. Image loading - Each image is loaded and processed
  2. Perceptual hashing - A "fingerprint" is created based on visual content
  3. Comparison - Images with similar fingerprints are grouped together

Perceptual Hashing

Perceptual hashing creates a hash based on what the image looks like, not its exact bytes. This means it can detect similar images even if they have different resolutions, formats, or minor edits.

docs.title: Options
docs.text: Flag Description Default --threshold Similarity threshold (0-64) 5 --delete Delete similar images --trash Move to trash --execute -e Execute deletion

docs.title: Threshold
docs.text:
The threshold controls how similar images must be to match:

Threshold Meaning 0-2 Nearly identical (same image, different format) 3-5 Very similar (minor crops, resizes) 6-10 Somewhat similar (different angles, edits) 11+ Loosely similar (may include false positives)

Start Low

Start with a low threshold (2-3) and increase if you want to find more matches.

neatcli similar ~/Photos

Output:

    ○ /Users/you/Photos/photo_edited.jpg (4.8 MB) - distance: 2
    ○ /Users/you/Photos/photo_small.jpg (1.1 MB) - distance: 3

  Group 2 (Original: sunset.png):
    ● /Users/you/Photos/sunset.png (8.0 MB)
    ○ /Users/you/Photos/sunse_crop.jpg (2.5 MB) - distance: 4

Summary: 3 similar images in 2 groups
Potential space savings: 8.4 MB

neatcli similar ~/Photos --threshold 2

docs.text:
# Move similar images to trash
neatcli similar ~/Photos --delete --trash --execute

docs.title: undo
docs.text: Undo the last file operation.

docs.title: Usage
docs.text: neatcli undo

docs.title: How It Works
docs.text:
NeatCLI keeps a history of all file operations:

  • Moves can be undone (files are moved back)
  • Deletes cannot be undone (use --trash instead)

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

docs.title: Limitations
docs.text:
Deleted Files

Files deleted with clean --execute (without --trash) cannot be recovered. Always use --trash for safer cleanup operations.

History Size

By default, the last 100 operations are kept. Older operations are automatically removed.

docs.text: Watch a directory and auto-organize new files as they appear.

docs.title: Usage
docs.text: neatcli watch [OPTIONS] <PATH>

docs.title: Options
docs.text: Flag Description --by-type Organize by file type (default) --by-date Organize by date --by-extension Organize by extension --config Use custom config file --auto Auto-confirm without prompts

neatcli watch ~/Downloads --auto

docs.title: With Custom Config
docs.text: neatcli watch ~/Downloads --config ~/.neat/custom.toml

docs.title: How It Works
docs.text:
1. NeatCLI monitors the directory for new files
  2. When a file is created or modified, it's detected
  3. The file is organized according to the selected mode
  4. With --auto, this happens immediately; otherwise, you're prompted

Background Service

For permanent background watching, consider setting up a launchd (macOS) or systemd (Linux) service.

docs.title: Full Workflow
docs.text:
#!/bin/bash

MUSIC_DIR=~/Music

# 1. Remove duplicates first
neatcli duplicates $MUSIC_DIR --delete --trash --execute

# 2. Organize by album
neatcli organize $MUSIC_DIR --by-album --execute

# 3. Show statistics
neatcli stats $MUSIC_DIR

docs.title: Supported Formats
docs.text:
NeatCLI can read metadata from:

Format Extensions Metadata MP3 .mp3 ID3v1, ID3v2 FLAC .flac Vorbis comments M4A/AAC .m4a, .aac iTunes tags OGG .ogg Vorbis comments WAV .wav Limited

docs.title: Tips
docs.text:
Tagging First

For best results, ensure your music files have proper metadata tags. Tools like MusicBrainz Picard or Kid3 can help auto-tag files.

Compilations

Compilation albums may have different artists per track. --by-album keeps compilation albums together.

│   └── _DSC0001.jpg
└── Sony A7 III/
    └── DSC00001.jpg

docs.title: By File Date
docs.text:
Fallback for photos without EXIF:

neatcli organize ~/Photos --by-date --execute

Uses file modification date instead of EXIF date taken.

docs.title: Only Large Photos
docs.text:
# Photos larger than 5MB (skip thumbnails)
neatcli organize ~/Photos --min-size 5MB --execute

docs.title: Only JPEGs
docs.text: neatcli organize ~/Photos --mime "image/jpeg" --execute

docs.title: iPhone Photos Only
docs.text:
# Filter by filename pattern
neatcli organize ~/Photos --startswith "IMG_" --execute

docs.title: Photos from 2024
docs.text: neatcli organize ~/Photos --after 2024-01-01 --before 2025-01-01 --execute

docs.title: Find Duplicate Photos
docs.text:
# Find exact duplicates
neatcli duplicates ~/Photos

# Delete duplicates (keeps first copy)
neatcli duplicates ~/Photos --delete --trash --execute

docs.title: Find Similar Photos
docs.text:
Find near-duplicates (different sizes, edits, exports):

# Default threshold
neatcli similar ~/Photos

# Stricter matching
neatcli similar ~/Photos --threshold 3

# Delete similar photos
neatcli similar ~/Photos --delete --trash --execute

docs.title: Copy from SD Card
docs.text:
# Copy (not move) and organize by date taken
neatcli organize /Volumes/SD_CARD/DCIM \
  --by-date-taken \
  --copy \
  --execute

docs.title: Verify Import
docs.text:
# Check for duplicates after import
neatcli duplicates ~/Photos

# Get statistics
neatcli stats ~/Photos

docs.title: Full Workflow Example
docs.text:
Complete photo organization workflow:

#!/bin/bash

PHOTOS_DIR=~/Photos

# 1. Import from SD card
if [ -d "/Volumes/SD_CARD/DCIM" ]; then
  neatcli organize /Volumes/SD_CARD/DCIM \
    --by-date-taken \
    --copy \
    --execute
fi

# 2. Remove duplicates
neatcli duplicates $PHOTOS_DIR --delete --trash --execute

# 3. Find similar images for review
neatcli similar $PHOTOS_DIR --threshold 3

# 4. Show statistics
neatcli stats $PHOTOS_DIR

docs.title: Tips
docs.text:
EXIF Data

--by-date-taken uses EXIF DateTimeOriginal, which is the actual capture time. --by-date uses file modification date, which may change when copying files.

RAW + JPEG

If you shoot RAW+JPEG, both files will have the same name but different extensions. Use --by-extension to separate them, or keep them together with --by-date-taken.

Screenshots

To exclude screenshots, use: 

neatcli organize ~/Photos --regex "^(?!Screenshot)" --execute

docs.title: Common Workflows
docs.text: Real-world examples of using NeatCLI for everyday tasks.

docs.title: Weekly Downloads Cleanup
docs.text:
Clean up your Downloads folder every week:

# 1. Preview what will be organized
neatcli organize ~/Downloads

# 2. Organize by type
neatcli organize ~/Downloads --execute

# 3. Remove old files (older than 30 days)
neatcli clean ~/Downloads --older-than 30d --trash --execute

# 4. Find and remove duplicates
neatcli duplicates ~/Downloads --delete --trash --execute

docs.title: Photo Import Workflow
docs.text:
When importing photos from a camera:

# 1. Copy (not move) from SD card, organize by date taken
neatcli organize /Volumes/SD_CARD/DCIM \
  --by-date-taken \
  --copy \
  --execute

# 2. Find duplicate photos
neatcli duplicates ~/Photos --delete --trash --execute

# 3. Find similar photos (duplicates with edits)
neatcli similar ~/Photos --threshold 5

# 4. Organize by camera model
neatcli organize ~/Photos --by-camera --execute

docs.title: Music Library Organization
docs.text:
Organize a messy music collection:

# 1. Organize by artist
neatcli organize ~/Music --by-artist --execute

# 2. Or organize by album (Artist/Album structure)
neatcli organize ~/Music --by-album --execute

# 3. Find duplicate songs
neatcli duplicates ~/Music --delete --trash --execute

docs.title: Project Archival
docs.text:
Archive old project files:

# 1. Find old project files (> 1 year)
neatcli stats ~/Projects

# 2. Preview old files
neatcli clean ~/Projects --older-than 1y

# 3. Move to archive (using organize by date)
neatcli organize ~/Projects --by-date --after 2023-01-01 --before 2024-01-01 --execute

docs.title: Automated Downloads Organization
docs.text:
Set up auto-organization with watch mode:

# Start watching Downloads folder
neatcli watch ~/Downloads --auto

Or create a shell alias:

# Add to ~/.bashrc or ~/.zshrc
alias clean-downloads='neatcli organize ~/Downloads --execute && neatcli clean ~/Downloads --older-than 30d --trash --execute'

docs.title: Disk Space Recovery
docs.text:
Find and remove space-wasting files:

# 1. Get statistics
neatcli stats ~/

# 2. Find large duplicates (> 100MB)
neatcli duplicates ~/ --min-size 100MB

# 3. Find similar large images
neatcli similar ~/Pictures --min-size 5MB

# 4. Clean old files
neatcli clean ~/Downloads --older-than 90d --trash --execute

docs.title: Backup Cleanup
docs.text:
Clean up backup folder duplicates:

# Find duplicates between original and backup
neatcli duplicates ~/Backup --delete --trash --execute

# Or find duplicates in specific folders
neatcli duplicates ~/Pictures ~/Backup/Pictures --delete --trash --execute

docs.title: Configuration
docs.text: NeatCLI can be customized using a configuration file and ignore files.

docs.title: Configuration File
docs.text:
Create a configuration file at ~/.neat/config.toml:

neatcli config init

docs.title: Example Configuration
docs.text:
# Custom rules for organizing files
[[rules]]
name = "Invoices"
pattern = "*invoice*.pdf"
destination = "Documents/Invoices/{year}"
priority = 10

[[rules]]
name = "Screenshots"
pattern = "Screenshot*.png"
destination = "Images/Screenshots/{year}-{month}"
priority = 5

[[rules]]
name = "Downloads Archive"
pattern = "*.zip"
destination = "Archives/{year}"
priority = 3

# Global settings
[settings]
include_hidden = false
follow_symlinks = false
default_organize_mode = "by-type"

docs.title: Rule Fields
docs.text: Field Description Required name Display name for the rule Yes pattern Glob pattern to match files Yes destination Target folder (supports variables) Yes priority Higher priority rules match first No

docs.title: Variables
docs.text:
Use these variables in destination:

Variable Example Description {year} 2024 Current year {month} 01 Current month (01-12) {day} 15 Current day (01-31)

docs.title: Settings
docs.text: Setting Default Description include_hidden false Include hidden files (starting with .) follow_symlinks false Follow symbolic links default_organize_mode by-type Default organization mode

docs.title: Ignore File
docs.text:
Create a .neatignore file in any directory to exclude files:

# Comments start with #
*.tmp
*.bak
node_modules
.git
.DS_Store
Thumbs.db

Patterns follow glob syntax, similar to .gitignore.

docs.title: CLI Options
docs.text:
Many settings can also be passed via command line:

# Ignore patterns
neatcli organize ~/Downloads --ignore "*.tmp" --ignore "*.bak"

# Include hidden files
# (not available via CLI, use config file)

docs.title: View Current Config
docs.text:
neatcli config show

Output: 

→ Config: /Users/you/.neat/config.toml

Rules:
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
  • Invoices (priority: 10)
    Pattern: *invoice*.pdf
    Dest:    Documents/Invoices/{year}

  • Screenshots (priority: 5)
    Pattern: Screenshot*.png
    Dest:    Images/Screenshots/{year}-{month}

Settings:
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
  Include hidden: false
  Follow symlinks: false
  Default mode: by-type

docs.title: Installation
docs.text: NeatCLI can be installed in several ways depending on your platform and preferences.

docs.title: Cargo (Recommended)
docs.text:
If you have Rust installed, the easiest way is via cargo:

cargo install neatcli

This will download, compile, and install the latest version from crates.io.

Requirements

Rust 1.70 or later is required.

docs.title: Homebrew (macOS/Linux)
docs.text:
For macOS and Linux users, NeatCLI is available via Homebrew:

brew tap patchybean/tap
brew install neatcli

To upgrade to the latest version: 

brew upgrade neatcli

docs.title: Pre-built Binaries
docs.text:
Pre-built binaries are available for:

Platform Architecture Download macOS Apple Silicon (M1/M2/M3) neatcli-aarch64-apple-darwin.tar.gz macOS Intel x86_64 neatcli-x86_64-apple-darwin.tar.gz Linux x86_64 neatcli-x86_64-unknown-linux-gnu.tar.gz

Download and extract: 

tar -xzf neatcli-*.tar.gz
sudo mv neatcli /usr/local/bin/

docs.title: From Source
docs.text:
Clone and build from source:

git clone https://github.com/patchybean/neatcli.git
cd neatcli
cargo build --release

The binary will be at target/release/neatcli.

docs.title: Verify Installation
docs.text:
Check that NeatCLI is installed correctly:

neatcli --version

Expected output: 

neatcli 0.3.0

docs.title: Shell Completions
docs.text:
Generate shell completions for your shell:

BashZshFish 
neatcli completions bash > ~/.local/share/bash-completion/completions/neatcli

neatcli completions zsh > ~/.zfunc/_neatcli

neatcli completions fish > ~/.config/fish/completions/neatcli.fish

docs.title: Quick Start
docs.text: This guide will walk you through the basics of using NeatCLI to organize your files.

docs.title: Your First Organization
docs.text:
Let's organize a messy Downloads folder:

neatcli organize ~/Downloads

This will preview what will happen without making any changes:

→ Scanning /Users/you/Downloads (organizing by type)...

Preview:
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

  Images (15 files)
    → photo.jpg
    → screenshot.png
    → diagram.svg
    → ... and 12 more

  Documents (8 files)
    → report.pdf
    → notes.txt
    → invoice.docx
    → ... and 5 more

  Videos (3 files)
    → recording.mp4
    → tutorial.mov
    → clip.avi

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

Summary: 26 files to move (1.2 GB)

ℹ Use --execute to execute these changes.

Dry-run by Default

NeatCLI always shows a preview first. Nothing is changed until you add --execute.

docs.title: Execute the Organization
docs.text:
When you're happy with the preview, run with --execute:

neatcli organize ~/Downloads --execute

Your files will be moved into organized folders:

Downloads/
├── Images/
│   ├── photo.jpg
│   ├── screenshot.png
│   └── ...
├── Documents/
│   ├── report.pdf
│   └── ...
└── Videos/
    └── recording.mp4

docs.title: Organization Modes
docs.text: NeatCLI supports multiple organization modes:

docs.title: By Type (Default)
docs.text:
neatcli organize ~/Downloads --by-type --execute
Creates folders: Images/, Documents/, Videos/, Audio/, Archives/, Code/

docs.title: By Date
docs.text:
neatcli organize ~/Photos --by-date --execute
Creates folders: 2024/01/, 2024/02/, etc.

docs.title: By Extension
docs.text:
neatcli organize ~/Downloads --by-extension --execute
Creates folders: PDF/, JPG/, MP4/, etc.

docs.title: By Camera (EXIF)
docs.text:
neatcli organize ~/Photos --by-camera --execute
Creates folders: iPhone 15 Pro/, Canon EOS R5/, etc.

docs.title: By Date Taken (EXIF)
docs.text:
neatcli organize ~/Photos --by-date-taken --execute
Uses the actual photo date from EXIF metadata.

docs.title: By Artist (Audio)
docs.text:
neatcli organize ~/Music --by-artist --execute
Creates folders: The Beatles/, Taylor Swift/, etc.

docs.title: By Album
docs.text:
neatcli organize ~/Music --by-album --execute
Creates folders: Artist/Album/

docs.title: Filtering Files
docs.text: You can filter which files to organize:

docs.title: By Size
docs.text:
# Only files larger than 10MB
neatcli organize ~/Downloads --min-size 10MB --execute

# Only files smaller than 100MB
neatcli organize ~/Downloads --max-size 100MB --execute

docs.title: By Date
docs.text:
# Only files modified after January 2024
neatcli organize ~/Downloads --after 2024-01-01 --execute

docs.title: By Name
docs.text:
# Only files starting with "IMG_"
neatcli organize ~/Photos --startswith "IMG_" --execute

# Only files containing "2024"
neatcli organize ~/Documents --contains "2024" --execute

docs.title: By MIME Type
docs.text:
# Only images
neatcli organize ~/Downloads --mime "image/*" --execute

# Only PDFs
neatcli organize ~/Downloads --mime "application/pdf" --execute

docs.title: Copy Instead of Move
docs.text:
Use --copy to copy files instead of moving them:

neatcli organize ~/Downloads --copy --execute

Original files remain in place; organized copies are created.

docs.title: Undo Changes
docs.text:
Made a mistake? Undo the last operation:

neatcli undo

View your operation history: 

neatcli history

docs.title: Filters Reference
docs.text: NeatCLI provides powerful filtering options to select exactly which files to process.

docs.title: Name Filters
docs.text: Filter files based on their filename.

docs.title: --startswith
docs.text:
Match files whose name starts with a string:

neatcli organize ~/Photos --startswith "IMG_" --execute

Matches: IMG_0001.jpg, IMG_vacation.png Doesn't match: photo.jpg, my_IMG_file.jpg

docs.title: --endswith
docs.text:
Match files whose name ends with a string (before extension):

neatcli organize ~/Downloads --endswith "_backup" --execute

Matches: file_backup.zip, data_backup.sql Doesn't match: backup.zip, backup_file.zip

docs.title: --contains
docs.text:
Match files whose name contains a string:

neatcli organize ~/Documents --contains "2024" --execute

Matches: report_2024.pdf, 2024_budget.xlsx, tax_2024_final.doc

docs.title: --regex
docs.text:
Use regular expressions for advanced matching:

# Files starting with IMG_ followed by 4 digits
neatcli organize ~/Photos --regex "^IMG_\d{4}" --execute

# Files with dates in format YYYY-MM-DD
neatcli organize ~/Downloads --regex "\d{4}-\d{2}-\d{2}" --execute

Regex Syntax

NeatCLI uses Rust regex syntax, which is similar to Perl/PCRE.

Common patterns:

Pattern Matches ^IMG_ Starts with "IMG_" \.pdf$ Ends with ".pdf" \d{4} 4 digits [A-Z]+ One or more uppercase letters .*backup.* Contains "backup" anywhere

docs.title: --mime
docs.text:
Filter by file type using MIME types:

# All images
neatcli organize ~/Downloads --mime "image/*" --execute

# Only JPEG images
neatcli organize ~/Downloads --mime "image/jpeg" --execute

# Only PDFs
neatcli organize ~/Downloads --mime "application/pdf" --execute

Common MIME types:

MIME Type Files image/* All images image/jpeg JPEG only image/png PNG only video/* All videos audio/* All audio application/pdf PDF documents application/zip ZIP archives text/* All text files text/plain Plain text

docs.title: Combining Filters
docs.text:
All filters can be combined. Files must match all specified filters:

# JPEG images larger than 5MB from 2024
neatcli organize ~/Photos \
  --mime "image/jpeg" \
  --min-size 5MB \
  --after 2024-01-01 \
  --execute

# Files starting with "IMG_" that contain "vacation"
neatcli organize ~/Photos \
  --startswith "IMG_" \
  --contains "vacation" \
  --execute

docs.title: See Also
docs.text:
• Size & Date Filters
  • MIME Types Reference

docs.title: MIME Types Reference
docs.text: Complete reference of MIME types for filtering files.

docs.title: Wildcard Matching
docs.text:
Use * to match all subtypes:

neatcli organize ~/Downloads --mime "image/*"   # All images
neatcli organize ~/Downloads --mime "video/*"   # All videos
neatcli organize ~/Downloads --mime "audio/*"   # All audio

docs.title: Images
docs.text: MIME Type Extensions image/jpeg .jpg, .jpeg image/png .png image/gif .gif image/webp .webp image/svg+xml .svg image/bmp .bmp image/tiff .tiff, .tif image/heic .heic image/heif .heif image/* All of the above

docs.title: Videos
docs.text: MIME Type Extensions video/mp4 .mp4 video/quicktime .mov video/x-msvideo .avi video/x-matroska .mkv video/webm .webm video/x-flv .flv video/mpeg .mpeg, .mpg video/* All of the above

docs.title: Audio
docs.text: MIME Type Extensions audio/mpeg .mp3 audio/wav .wav audio/flac .flac audio/aac .aac audio/ogg .ogg audio/x-m4a .m4a audio/midi .mid, .midi audio/* All of the above

docs.title: Documents
docs.text: MIME Type Extensions application/pdf .pdf application/msword .doc application/vnd.openxmlformats-officedocument.wordprocessingml.document .docx application/vnd.ms-excel .xls application/vnd.openxmlformats-officedocument.spreadsheetml.sheet .xlsx application/vnd.ms-powerpoint .ppt application/vnd.openxmlformats-officedocument.presentationml.presentation .pptx text/plain .txt text/markdown .md text/html .html text/csv .csv

docs.title: Archives
docs.text: MIME Type Extensions application/zip .zip application/gzip .gz application/x-tar .tar application/x-rar-compressed .rar application/x-7z-compressed .7z application/x-bzip2 .bz2

docs.title: Code
docs.text: MIME Type Extensions text/javascript .js text/x-python .py text/x-rust .rs text/x-c .c, .h text/x-java .java application/json .json application/xml .xml text/x-yaml .yaml, .yml

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
# Only PDF documents
neatcli organize ~/Documents --mime "application/pdf" --execute

# All images except GIFs
neatcli organize ~/Photos --mime "image/*" --regex ".*\.gif$" --execute

# Video files
neatcli organize ~/Downloads --mime "video/*" --execute

docs.title: Size & Date Filters
docs.text: Filter files by size and modification date.

docs.title: --min-size
docs.text:
Only include files larger than the specified size:

neatcli organize ~/Downloads --min-size 10MB --execute

docs.title: --max-size
docs.text:
Only include files smaller than the specified size:

neatcli organize ~/Downloads --max-size 100MB --execute

docs.title: Size Format
docs.text:
Format Example Bytes Bytes 1000 or 1000B 1,000 Kilobytes 100KB 100,000 Megabytes 50MB 50,000,000 Gigabytes 1GB 1,000,000,000

Base 10

Sizes use base 10 (1 KB = 1,000 bytes), not base 2 (1 KiB = 1,024 bytes).

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
# Files between 1MB and 100MB
neatcli organize ~/Downloads --min-size 1MB --max-size 100MB --execute

# Large images only
neatcli organize ~/Photos --mime "image/*" --min-size 5MB --execute

# Small documents
neatcli organize ~/Documents --max-size 500KB --execute

docs.title: --after
docs.text:
Only include files modified after the specified date:

neatcli organize ~/Downloads --after 2024-01-01 --execute

docs.title: --before
docs.text:
Only include files modified before the specified date:

neatcli organize ~/Downloads --before 2024-06-01 --execute

docs.title: Date Formats
docs.text:
Supported formats:

Format Example ISO 8601 2024-01-15 Slash 2024/01/15

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
# Files from 2024
neatcli organize ~/Downloads \
  --after 2024-01-01 \
  --before 2025-01-01 \
  --execute

# Files from last quarter
neatcli organize ~/Documents \
  --after 2024-10-01 \
  --execute

# Old files (before 2020)
neatcli clean ~/Archive --before 2020-01-01 --trash --execute

docs.title: Combining Size and Date
docs.text:
All filters work together:

# Large recent files
neatcli organize ~/Downloads \
  --min-size 50MB \
  --after 2024-06-01 \
  --execute

# Small old files (candidates for cleanup)
neatcli clean ~/Downloads \
  --max-size 1MB \
  --before 2024-01-01 \
  --trash \
  --execute
